repnme.cdata!: Benin - Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Poverty Reduction
            Support Credit Project (PRSC I) for Benin are as follows:
            outcome was satisfactory, risk to the development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also rated satisfactory. Ratings
            for the Second Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project
            (PRSC II) for Benin are as follows: outcome was moderately
            satisfactory, risk to the development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was rated moderately satisfactory. Ratings for
            the Third Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project (PRSC
            III) for Benin are as follows: outcome was moderately
            satisfactory, risk to the development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was rated moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: 1) selectivity and simplicity of the
            design are essential to the success of the operation.
            Obstacles due to administrative resistance to change, as
            well as due to lack of capacity cannot be underestimated. It
            is better to start with a very selective matrix and enlarge
            progressively, building on success in some components. There
            is also a need to be realistic about the scope and pace of
            reform; 2) it is important to properly align the PRSC with
            budget management, so that the priority components of the
            PRSC and the performance budgets of those ministries are
            supportive of each other. It is also important that budget
            support be phased with the budget cycle, in order to
            properly impact on budget composition, and to provide budget
            support in a timely manner; 3) the effectiveness of the
            PRSCs in supporting sector reforms can be highly increased
            by using a sector wide approach, as was successfully
            experienced in rural water supply. The approach federated
            donors around the government's objectives and allowed a
            mix of central government programs, decentralized programs,
            budget support and projects to combine efficiently; and 4)
            PRSCs (I-III) rightly focused on the critical areas of
            governance and basic service delivery. Future PRSCs need to
            deepen support in the areas of reforms where progress has
            been slow and focus on critical bottlenecks rather than
            broadening the areas of support to new areas.

repnme.cdata!: Benin - Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Benin Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Project had a satisfactory outcome, likely
            sustainability, modest institutional development impact, and
            satisfactory performances by both Bank and Borrower. The
            following are findings and implications for subsequent
            operations: 1) The work under a prior operation in
            developing government experience in results-budgeting was
            highly instrumental in successfully implementing the
            project. Nevertheless, monitoring and evaluation capacity in
            most ministries was still fragile and limited. Team dialogue
            with Government should devote greater attention to the
            result-framework and indicators, and to related capacity
            building activities. The main stakeholders'
            understanding of the Poverty Reduction Support Credit (PRSC)
            process and requirements was fragile and required
            improvements over time. Greater team efforts to expand
            stakeholder understanding and ownership would have improved
            the environment for subsequent operations. Donor
            coordination mechanisms needed to be enhanced so as to lay
            the ground for greater harmonization of procedures. Such
            harmonization was essential both to simplify messages for
            Government but also to enhance the efficiency of reform
            programs and of donor support. Starting with three sectors
            was an ambitious beginning, and for the included themes the
            policy matrix was quite long and detailed. It would be
            better for the team and Government to work to simplify the matrix.

repnme.cdata!:
Benin - Poverty Reduction Support Credit
            Project : environmental analysis

abstracts.cdata!:
This is environmental assessment for the
            Benin Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project, which
            strengthens the Government's capacity to design and
            carry out its development and poverty reduction programs.
            analyses potential environmental and social impacts. Key
            safeguard issues are mainly related to the drilling of wells
            for the rural water supply, and medical waste generation and
            handling. Such impacts are expected to be modest and
            reversible through mitigation measures. Activities related
            to forests and adjacent lands management are part of broader
            programs spanning a five-year period, although those
            activities planned for this project do not appear to
            generate any adverse environmental impacts. Hence the
            environmental and social management plan for PRSC-2 will
            include appropriate guidance aimed at mitigating expected
            negative impacts. Sector-specific measures aimed at
            mitigating negative impacts forPRSC-1 include the following:
            To protect the water supply, complete a mandatory impact
            assessment for the dam; avoid unsanitary sites (cemeteries,
            cattle pens, etc); control wastewater and mud around wells;
            sensitize users about hygiene; and impose restrictions on
            the distance between well and latrines. To manage medical
            wastes, train personnel, acquire health care equipment and
            use incinerators. To reduce impacts surrounding urban
            sanitation, help update the 1998 master sanitation plan by
            selecting high priority low-income areas where urgent
            improvement of sanitation services is needed in order to
            reduce the burden of environment-related diseases. However
            investments in earthworks and dam construction will not
            start until 2005.

repnme.cdata!: Benin - Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Poverty Reduction Support Credit
            Project is designed to help implement the Benin's
            December 2002 Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP), by
            supporting key policy measures aiming at: a) bolstering the
            medium-term macroeconomic framework; b) improving service
            delivery; and, c) enhancing governance and institutional
            capacity. The focus of the project will be on further
            supporting selective cross-cutting themes, critical to
            improving service delivery, in particular, the public
            expenditure management reform, undertaken under the Public
            Expenditure Reform Adjustment Credit. Attention shall be
            given to three core sectors: rural water, health, and basic
            education. In addition to these three sectors, the project
            would support continuation on the implementation of the
            Environment and Urban Sanitation, and Forest Management
            programs, ensuring proper funding, execution and monitoring.
            While the programmatic approach should increase Benin's
            ownership of its development programs, strengthen budgetary
            institutions and reduce transactions costs in the delivery
            of external assistance, in addition to the promotion of
            inter-sectoral coordination, maximizing the impact on
            poverty reduction, risks could influence project outcomes.
            This entails the economy's vulnerability to falling
            cotton prices, which may hamper growth and significant
            reduction in poverty, in addition to the economic and
            political developments in Nigeria. Further risks are
            possible slippages in key reforms, weak institutional
            capacity; and, fiduciary risks. However, these risks have
            been mitigated by the strength of the Government's
            ownership and commitment to implement the proposed measures,
            and significant up-front actions.
